description: The oceans play a pivotal role in drawing down atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO₂) and have so far acted as a brake on the full impact of climate change. Current estimates of the CO₂ from the atmosphere that disappears in the ocean, commonly referred to as the ocean CO₂ sink, suggests that around 25% of all human CO₂ emissions have been taken up by the oceans.
title: How we discovered that the ocean's surface absorbs much more carbon dioxide than previously thought

description: Say hello to Strawberry Claws, a large new-to-science species of hermit crab recently described by Queensland Museum scientists.
title: Meet Strawberry Claws—a new species of hermit crab

description: As we tidy away the Dracula capes and glow-in-the-dark plastic fangs for another winter, one notorious blood sucker has had a particularly good year.
title: Leeches are making a medical comeback—here's why we should celebrate it

description: In a new study published in Nature Communications, scientists have implemented the topologically ordered time crystal on a quantum processor for the first time.
title: Implementing topologically ordered time crystals on quantum processors

description: Facial recognition technology is becoming more widely used, but this has not been matched by wider acceptance from the public.
title: In your face: our acceptance of facial recognition technology depends on who is doing it—and where

description: Scientists believe individuals of the most recently discovered hominin group (the Denisovans) that interbred with modern day humans passed on some of their genes via multiple, distinct interbreeding events that helped shape early human history.
title: New insights into the Denisovans—the hominin group that interbred with modern day humans

description: This week, researchers hypothesized that human culture is distinguished from cultures of other species like whales by unique open-endedness—the ability to communicate and understand an infinite number of possibilities. An ancient unicellular organism provided evidence that embryonic development evolved before actual animals. And researchers reported that the Earth experienced a massive, rapid melting period following the last ice age. Additionally, we reported on the sociological implications of blowing deadlines, a method to calculate the mass and spin of a black hole, and the evolution of species coloration.
title: Saturday Citations: Color vision created demand for colorful animals; observing black hole light echoes; deadlines!

description: Standing at a woodland entrance to the world's longest cave system in Kentucky, a park ranger warns those about to enter of an extremely deadly fungus—not for humans, but for the bat populations it has devastated across North America.
title: New tools give researchers hope for fungus-ravaged US bats
